frontmatter.title: PDF as a Read It Later Service
frontmatter.summary: PDF seems to be the best format to read books on iPad, and now I've started using it for reading web long reads as well. Being in control is the best part: You can decide how the website looks like, save it so it's yours to read and annotate however you like, and store it forever.

frontmatter.title: Inoreader vs Feedly, and the ultimate feed reader (in 2020)
frontmatter.summary: I started to use RSS again and setting the system up requires some work. I also noticed that my needs are so specific that each service does not support them fully. I have compared Feedly and Inoreader, and in the process found out the feature set that matters to me. Choosing which service to use is hard, because none of them is perfect. Some services can also be surprisingly expensive.

frontmatter.title: Feeds Are The Future
frontmatter.summary: I was using RSS a lot around 2013, and I want to go back. I'd like to be more in control on what stories I see each day. At the same time I know the amount of items in RSS feeds can be overwhelming, so I'm excited to try out new tools to combat information overload as well. I'm glad to see that RSS is not *dead*, even though I understand it probably should evolve. Feed aggregators must evolve as well, or there might not be enough sources for them in the future.

frontmatter.title: Augment, Complement and Empower Human Cognitive Skills
frontmatter.summary: Expert group for EU has published Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI. The document specifies a list of requirements the systems should meet to be considered trustworthy. They also define a rough framework and an assessment list to offer guidance on practical implementation. The objective is to empower humans and offer them meaningful work instead of replacing them. Augmenting human abilities is an approach I'm happy to advocate for.

frontmatter.title: Platformer (game) UX
frontmatter.summary: Some years ago I tried building a platformer game (PC / Android) and found the experience interesting from the UX point of view. This is my recap of what I remember. TLDR: You can cheat to make it feel more like a game. Physics simulation rarely makes a good platformer (although Trine might beg to differ). At least you'll need to fine-tune your character movement physics.
